content: Yajin Zhou â Web3 & Systems Security Researcher (Zhejiang University) "If you want to set off and go develop some grand new thing, you don't need millions of dollars of capitalization. You need enough pizza and Diet Coke to stick in your refrigerator, a cheap PC to work on, and the dedication to go through with it." â John Carmack About I am a ZJU 100âYoung Professor at the College of Computer Science and Technology, Zhejiang University. I earned my Ph.D. in Computer Science from North Carolina State University in 2015 (Advisor: Prof. Xuxian Jiang) and subsequently served as a Senior Security Researcher at Qihoo 360. I am also a coâfounder of BlockSec, a company providing blockchain security and compliance solutions. I have published 70+ papers with 10,000+ citations (see Google Scholar). One of my papers was included in the normalized list of Topâ100 Security Papers since 1981, and I received the Most Influential Scholar Award for contributions to Security and Privacy. I currently serve as Chief Scientist (PI) of a National Key R&D Program funded by China's Ministry of Science and Technology, a PC member/reviewer for IEEE S&P, USENIX Security, and ACM CCS, and an expert reviewer for funding programs in Singapore, France, and Hong Kong. AtâaâGlance 70+ publications; 10,000+ citations Topâ100 influential security paper (normalized list) Most Influential Scholar Award (Security & Privacy) PI/Chief Scientist, National Key R&D Program PC: IEEE S&P, USENIX, CCS, FC Funding program reviewer: Singapore, France, Hong Kong Founding BlockSec, a blockchain security and compliance startup company backed by top-tier investors and serving 500+ global clients including exchanges, regulators, and enterprises. Research My research spans system and blockchain security, including software security, operating system security, and hardware-assisted security, with an increasing focus on emerging areas such as smart-contract security, DeFi security, and the underground cybercrime. I continue to advance problems across traditional system security while building end-to-end protection for modern blockchain ecosystems. Impact Many of my academic results have been adopted into productionânot only at BlockSec, but earlier at Qihoo 360. This includes our early Android security work that advanced mobile security: techniques for malware detection and anti-repackaging/anti-piracy were productized and deployed at scale. Our blockchain research has helped prevent multi-million-dollar attacks and support on-chain investigations for regulators and law-enforcement worldwide. A tight two-way loop between industry and academia turns security incidents and real-world needs into sharper research questions, while academic inquiry abstracts root causes and opens new directions that feed back into productsâsustaining true academy-industry synergy.
